Description: Lower body and flaring foot of South Ionian pottery cup, probably a cup with everted rim; wholly glazed save the underside; inscription on resting surface.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

In all likelihood one of the pieces found by Hogarth in the 'Dioscuri chamber' in the southwestern corner of the Hellenion, not far from the sanctuary of the Dioskouroi: "The first point at which any considerable find of inscriptions was made, was at 34, where in the corner of a small chamber abutting west on the great enclosure wall, which runs north, a number of dedications to the Dioscuri were discovered about 2 ft. above the mud. Just south of the southern wall of this small chamber and at a similar level occurred the lamp with Dioscuri dedication (No. 57); and south again of this, up to the line of the E.-W. enclosure wall, were found (scattered partly on the surface in sebakh-diggers' and rubbish heaps, partly a foot or two above the mud) a few dedications to Herakles (Nos. 33, 84), mixed with stray sherds of Apollo (No. 52), Artemis? (No. 65), and others not to be identified, including the inscribed stone horse (No. 58), which like two other horses found by the sebakh-diggers close to this same point, lay in untouched earth almost immediately upon the mud." (Hogarth et al. 1898-9, p. 30).

Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, the ring foot and slip find parallels with his South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 5 or Type 9. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18). The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Type 5 cups are few at Naukratis whereas there are numerous examples of Type 9 cups. Both types were common drinking vessels found in Greeks sanctuaries, including the sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra.
Bibliographic references: Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 699, no. 571)
Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 55, no. 49)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.248) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
